comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: what a wonderful family portrait, very well done and great quality

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Indeed it is, but I'm actually a little concerned about the Currans. This photo was taken on 19 July 1900, and there are 4 children, one daughter and 3 sons (going by dress habits for young boys in that era). The 1901 census, taken on 31 March 1901, has a Curran family living at 6 Bridge Street, but now we're down to 3 children in total: Kathleen, 8; Michael, 7; and Edmund, 3. Don't know about you, but 3 of these children look as if those ages of 8, 7, and 3 would tally with their ages 8 months after this photo was taken. Wonder if one of the littlest boys had died... Have a look for yourselves: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai001234756/
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice Photo. Well Taken. Lovely Family. ( no Internet back then )

comment.author: 57099931@N05
comment._content: The Curran's return for the 1911 census show six children born and five living.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/57099931@N05] Yes, indeed, checked that out. Also interesting to see that the Curran's servant, 20 year old Mary Horan had been born in Africa! Would love to know where, and what brought her to Waterford...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Oh, and Mr John Curran had obviously died before 1911, as Mary Curran (40) is now listed as head of the family (John had been a full 19 years older than his wife). www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Waterford/Water...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 11224990@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] This is fantastic, even if it is sad...  I love the research you are doing to fill in the blanks on the people in the photos.  Thank you!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pirategen] You're very welcome! It's absolutely fascinating how much can be reconstructed after over a century...
